user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (const char *str,
                             const char *const token,
                             size_t token_len)
{
  if (0 == token_len)
    return false;

  while (0 != *str)
  {
    size_t i;
    /* Skip all whitespaces and empty tokens. */
    while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str || ',' == *str)
      str++;

    /* Check for token match. */
    i = 0;
    while (1)
    {
      const char sc = *(str++);
      const char tc = token[i++];

      if (0 == sc)
        return false;
      if (! charsequalcaseless (sc, tc))
        break;
      if (i >= token_len)
      {
        /* Check whether substring match token fully or
         * has additional unmatched chars at tail. */
        while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str)
          str++;
        /* End of (sub)string? */
        if ((0 == *str) || (',' == *str) )
          return true;
        /* Unmatched chars at end of substring. */
        break;
      }
    }
    /* Find next substring. */
    while (0 != *str && ',' != *str)
      str++;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Reasons: 

- All pointer parameters in the shown code are to const-qualified types: the function under inspection declares the input string as "const char *str" and the token as "const char *const token". Both point to const-qualified char data, satisfying the requirement that pointers point to const-qualified types whenever possible.

- There are no other pointer variables (no non-const pointers to data) in the function body; local variables derived from pointers (sc, tc) are char values, not pointers, so Rule 8.13 does not apply to them.

- The helper function charsequalcaseless accepts char by value (const char c1, const char c2) rather than pointers, so it is outside the scope of Rule 8.13.

- Pointer arithmetic in the code (increments of str and indexing of token) only reads the pointed-to data; it does not modify the pointee, so preserving the pointed-to const qualification is appropriate and already done.

Therefore, there are no fragments in the provided code that appear to violate Rule 8.13.
